facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 105 of 1953 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 105 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by Supreme Court on 24th September 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by this Courts Order dated the 24th September, 1951 from the Judgment and Decree dated the 2nd day of September, 1949

facts.text: High Court of Judicature at Bombay delivered Judgment and Decree on 2nd September 1949 in Appeal No. 274 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by this Courts Order dated the 24th September, 1951 from the Judgment and Decree dated the 2nd day of September, 1949 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal No. 274 of 1948

facts.text: Court of Civil Judge, Senior Division at Hubli passed decree on 30th July 1946 in Special Suit No. 56 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Decree dated the 2nd day of September, 1949 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal No. 274 of 1948 from Original Decree arising out of the Decree dated the 30th day of July, 1946 of the Court of Civil Judge, Senior Division at Hubli in Special Suit No. 56 of 1944.

facts.text: Appellant Gurunath instituted suit on 15th March 1944 in forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: On the 15th of March, 1944 the appellant instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises in forma pauperis on the allegation that he was the adopted son of Krishtarao and adopted to him by Gangabai, his junior widow,

facts.text: Gurunath claims he was adopted in 1943 by Gangabai, widow of Krishtarao.

anchor.surface_text: Gurunath, the plaintiff, claims that he was adopted in 1943 by Gangabai, widow of Krishtarao. Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving him surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai

facts.text: Krishtarao died in 1890 leaving surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai and a son Dattatraya.

anchor.surface_text: Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving him surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai and a son Dattatraya. Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving him surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath.

facts.text: Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving surviving widow Sundarabai and son Jagannath.

anchor.surface_text: Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving him surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath. Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914.

facts.text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya in 1913.

anchor.surface_text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914. After an interval of about 30 years since his death, it is alleged that Gangabai who survived both her son,

facts.text: Jagannath died in 1914.

anchor.surface_text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914. After an interval of about 30 years since his death, it is alleged that Gangabai who survived both her son,

facts.text: Gangabai adopted Gurunath after about 30 years since Jagannath's death.

anchor.surface_text: After an interval of about 30 years since his death, it is alleged that Gangabai who survived both her son, and grandson adopted the plaintiff, and thus raised the problem which we are called upon to solve.

facts.text: Plaintiff claims entitled to possession of Krishtarao's properties and declaration regarding compensation money for land acquired by Hubli Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that he was the adopted son of Krishtarao and adopted to him by Gangabai, his junior widow, and as such was entitled to the possession of his adoptive fathers properties comprised in the suit. He also claimed a declaration regarding the amount of compensation money payable to the plaintiffs family for the land acquired by Hubli Municipality.

facts.text: Defendants disputed plaintiff's adoption claiming Gangabai's power extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving widow Sundarabai and son Jagannath.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants who are the sons and grandsons of the first cousin of Krishtarao disputed the plaintiffs adoption on the ground that Gangabais power to adopt was extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913, leaving behind him a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath who could continue the family line.

facts.text: Gangabai in written statement supported plaintiff's claim and asserted Radhabai consented to adoption.

anchor.surface_text: Gangabai in her written statement supported the plaintiffs claim and asserted that the senior widow Radhabai had given consent to her adopting the plain- tiff.

facts.text: Trial judge upheld defendants' contention, dismissed suit, upheld factum of adoption but held Radhabai did not give consent.

anchor.surface_text: The trial judge upheld the defendants contention and dismissed the plaintiffs suit. The factum of the plaintiffs adoption was however upheld, and it was further held that Radhabai did not give her consent to the adoption.

facts.text: High Court affirmed trial court decision holding Gangabai's power to adopt ended when her son died leaving son and widow.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal this decision was affirmed by the High Court and it was held that Gangabais power to adopt came to an end at the time when her son died leaving a son and a widow to continue the family line.

facts.text: High Court gave no finding on whether Radhabai consented to adoption.

anchor.surface_text: No finding was given on the question whether Radhabai had given her consent to the adop- tion. That perhaps would have been the simplest way to end the dispute.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court in forma pauperis by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the High 1139 Court this appeal in forma pauperis is now before us by special leave.

facts.text: Gurunath adopted by Gangabai on 18-11-43.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on December 10, 1954 by Mehr Chand Mahajan C.J.

anchor.surface_text: R. Bengeri and Sardar Bahadur for the appellant. B. Jathar and I. N. Shroff for respondents Nos. 3, 4 and 5. 1954. December 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MEHR CHAND MAHAJAN C. J.-

Appeal by Special Leave granted by this Courts Order dated the 24th September, 1951 from the Judgment and Decree dated the 2nd day of September, 1949
Against the decision of the High 1139 Court this appeal in forma pauperis is now before us by special leave.

concepts.unlisted_description: Judicially evolved rule that a widow's power to adopt extinguishes upon interposition of a grandson or son's widow competent to continue the family line.

concepts.interpretation: Validity of adoption determined by spiritual considerations rather than temporal devolution of property; essence is substitution for spiritual reasons.

arguments.claim: Duty passed to son then to grandson/son's widow ends mother's power; does not revive.

arguments.claim: Rule consistent with justice, equity, good conscience; part of Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: It is well known that in the absence of any clear Shastric text the courts have authority to decide cases on principles of justice, equity and good conscience and it is not possible to hold that the reasons stated in support of the rule are not consistent with these principles.

arguments.claim: Power ends by interposition of grandson or son's widow competent to continue line; per Amarendra.

anchor.surface_text: It being clear upon the decisions above referred to that the interposition of a grandson, or the sons widow, brings the mothers power of adoption to an end

arguments.claim: Once extinguished, power cannot revive; per Chandavarkar J. in Ramkrishna v Shamrao, affirmed in Madana Mohana.

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Chandavarkar, J. affirmed by the Judicial Committee in Madana Mohana v. Purushothama Deo the power having once been extinguished it cannot afterwards be revived.

arguments.claim: Widow's powers limited in inheritance, adoption; judicial limits consistent.

anchor.surface_text: Hindu Law generally and in particular in matters of inheritance, alienation and adoption gives to the widow powers of a limited character and there is nothing in the limitations laid down by the course of decisions

holdings.text: A widow's power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the son's widow competent to continue the line by adoption.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we are unable to depart from the rule that a widows power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to continue the line by adoption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmed by long series of Privy Council and High Court decisions over three quarters of a century; consistent with principles of justice, equity and good conscience; spiritual duty to continue line passes permanently to interposed heir.

holdings.text: Once the widow's power of adoption has been extinguished by interposition, it cannot afterwards be revived.

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Chandavarkar, J. affirmed by the Judicial Committee in Madana Mohana v. Purushothama Deo the power having once been extinguished it cannot afterwards be revived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Duty of continuing the line passes from mother to son to grandson or son's widow permanently; affirmed in Madana Mohana and Amarendra Mansingh; rejects revival logic.

holdings.text: The limits laid down in the decisions on widow's power of adoption have not been arbitrarily fixed and are based on sound principles.

anchor.surface_text: the point for our consideration is whether the limits laid down in these decisions have been arbitrarily fixed and are not based on sound principles and should be reviewed by us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule established in Chundrabullee, Thayammal, Ramkrishna, Amarendra; consistent with justice, equity, good conscience; no substantial grounds to review.

holdings.text: The rule that the power of a widow to adopt comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the son's widow competent to adopt has become a part of Hindu Law.

anchor.surface_text: the result of these series of decisions is, that now for about three quarters of a century the rule that the power of a widow to adopt comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to adopt has become a part of Hindu Law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled law absent clear Shastric text; courts fill via justice, equity, good conscience; no repugnancy to Hindu law doctrines.

holdings.text: The plaintiff's adoption by Gangabai is invalid as her power to adopt was extinguished when Dattatraya died leaving a widow Sundarabai and son Jagannath.

anchor.surface_text: The only question canvassed in the appeal is in respect to the validity of the plaintiffs adoption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of interposition rule to facts: power ended in 1913 upon son's death leaving competent continuators; adoption in 1943 too late.

holdings.text: The widow's duty of continuing the husband's line comes to an end upon the interposition of a grandson or the son's widow.

anchor.surface_text: The question at what point of time the widows duty of continuing the line of the husband comes to an end has been the subject-matter of a number of decisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established in Amarendra Mansingh: duty passes from father to son to grandson/son's widow; mere birth of son does not end it.

holdings.text: The decisions in Bapuji v. Gangaram (Nagpur) and Prem Jagat Kuer v. Harihar Bakhsh Singh (Lucknow) are erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment there is not only an obvious fallacy in this reasoning but it is based on a wrong apprehension of the true reasons stated for the rule in Amarendras case. The reason for the rule in Amarendras case was where the duty...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misapprehend Amarendra; wrongly infer revival on death/remarriage; duty ends permanently, no logic for revival.
